body:
@chrisgavin not needed now, it's for the future.

Also could you please add inspections for this kind of errors?

1) Add to Druid.xml:
```
    <inspection_tool class="MalformedFormatString" enabled="true" level="ERROR" enabled_by_default="true">
      <option name="additionalClasses" value="io.druid.java.util.common.StringUtils,io.druid.java.util.common.logger.Logger" />
      <option name="additionalMethods" value="trace,debug,info,warn,error,wtf,format,nonStrictFormat" />
    </inspection_tool>
```

2) Add to checkstyle.xml:
```
    <module name="Regexp">
      <property name="format" value="com\.metamx\.common\.logger"/>
      <property name="illegalPattern" value="true"/>
      <property name="message" value="Use io.druid.java.util.common.logger.Logger instead"/>
    </module>
```

3) I cannot find an inspection for unecessary use for boxed types (there is "unnecessary boxing" but it doesn't spot the places that you have found), but maybe there is some.

Or more generally, you may prohibit any non-druid loggers by regex like
```
(?<!io.druid.java.util.common.logger)\.Log(ger)?[^A-Za-z0-9]
```

But a few exceptions will be needed, that you may guard with `//CHECKSTYLE.OFF: Regexp` and `//CHECKSTYLE.ON: Regexp` comments.

@jihoonson, thank you for the super fast reply :)
A couple of follow up questions - 
1. What is the difference between 'merge task' and 'index task'?
2. If write some script (external to Druid) that looks at the segment layout and creates 'index tasks' to merge segments from the same time, is that expected to work ok, or would you still recommend Hadoop?
3. Both features that you referred to sound great, but they sound like a lot of work to me, wouldn't it be much easier to just change the coordinator to use index tasks instead of 'merge tasks'? or is there some reason this can't work?

Thanks again!

Eran
@niketh I don't understand what do you mean.

Among the suggested solutions I like adding `multiValueDelimiter`, because it allows to eventually remove listDelimiter in a way that is safe for user. Adding something like `nullListDelimiterAsDisable` it ugly and doesn't provide a way to clean the legacy later.

@erankor 

here are my answers.

1. Index task is a general task type that can be used for ingesting data from any dataSource even including druid's other dataSources. So, using index tasks, you can add new dataSources by ingesting external data to druid or reindex existing dataSources (http://druid.io/docs/latest/ingestion/update-existing-data.html). Here, the later is able to be used for the compaction effectively because index tasks can automatically determine more optmized shardSpec and segment size (please refer to [here](https://github.com/jihoonson/druid/blob/f85f17d66ab01da030012e0e1366d079a9056a9f/docs/content/design/index.md#roll-up-modes) for more details.) Meanwhile, merge tasks are capable of merging existing segments which have none shardSpec.
2. I recommend to use Hadoop index task for now because the native index task has some limitations like the potential out of disk problem (https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/4227) and slow ingestion due to the single processing model. This will be resolved in 0.11.0.
3. Unfortunately, it's not possible because of the limitation of our current segment versioning system. If you run a compaction task and a kafka index task at the same time, one of their result segments will be overshadowed and eventually removed. Please refer to https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/4479 for more details.
LGTM
@jihoonson, thank you very much for your support! Hadoop it is then... :)
@erankor cool! Feel free to further ask if you have more questions.

When the user does not specify multiValueDelimiter and listDelimiter, that means multiValueDelimiter = null and listDelimiter = null, and '\ u0001' will also be used as delimiter,
which could not fix this problem.  @leventov
@winval indeed. If so I'm in preference to `disableListDelimiter`, because it's simpler than `nullListDelimiterAsDisable`.
@winval @leventov what do you think about removing listDelimiter and adding multiValueDelimiter? Our next release will be a major release, so we can make a breaking change?

@pjain1 #1679 is a nice work and many parts are similar to this proposal. As a result, I think most codes of #1679 can be reused. If you don't mind, I'll make a new patch based on your work after resolving conflicts and adding some features needed in this proposal.
@chrisgavin it wasn't supposed to be clean, please fix inspection and checkstyle failures now.
@gianm @drcrallen @pjain1 I updated the proposal to include #1679.

See this [discussion](https://groups.google.com/forum/?utm_medium=email&utm_source=footer#!msg/druid-user/XuXJqrOwLXg/n1EBoP2mBAAJ). Maybe it would be good if users can specify ```multiValueDelimiter``` for each dimension.
can we add a unit test to make sure that this will not happen again ?
Pushed a new commit to resolve conflicts and address https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/4433#discussion_r125367680.

Will this lead to exceptions or crashes? Or 'weird' results? It's not obvious to me, at first glance, what is the best way to resolve the inconsistencies. The first two things that come to mind are,

- always treat null as 0
- treat null as "invalid number" (not `NaN` though) in cases where that makes sense -- so treat it as a parse exception when indexing, and don't allow it to match _any_ number in a value matcher, etc. In cases where it must be treated as a number (such as cases where there is an implicit or explicit cast to number) then treat it as 0.
@jihoonson, I pushed an updated patch, including a fix and test case for the problem with casting that you noticed.

Yes, item 1. in my list may lead to crashes, however float/long ingestion is not supported currently at all, because `toTimeAndDims()` uses `Row.getDimension()` that returns `List<String>` and will be unconditionally rejected by Long and Float indexers now. It should probably use `Row.getRaw()`?

I think it's reasonable to always treat null as 0, and parse errors as `NaN` (however currently parse errors are also mapped to 0). But `NaN` does match other `NaN` (at least it should be -- using conversion `floatToIntBits()`), it was my idea when float columns were introduced and I think it's reasonable.

Changes look good to me, although relating to @b-slim's point about testing:

`DimensionIndexer.makeObjectColumnSelector()` isn't actually called anywhere right now (`IncrementalIndexStorageAdapter.makeObjectColumnSelector()` uses `DimensionIndexer.convertUnsortedEncodedKeyComponentToActualArrayOrList()` instead)

I think we could actually remove makeObjectColumnSelector() method from DimensionIndexer

> I think we could actually remove makeObjectColumnSelector() method from DimensionIndexer

That seems better than fixing it… no reason to keep around an unnecessary method.
Given it's not actually used, I don't think this needs to be treated as an 0.10.1 blocking bug, so I'm moving it to 0.11.0.

For point 1:
Regarding crash/exception potential, `getUnsortedEncodedKeyComponentHashCode()` and `checkUnsortedEncodedKeyComponentsEqual()` will cause a NullPointerException on unparseable values, but `compareUnsortedEncodedKeyComponents()` won't since its call site checks for nulls before calling.

regarding this point:
> however float/long ingestion is not supported currently at all, because toTimeAndDims() uses Row.getDimension() that returns `List<String>` and will be unconditionally rejected by Long and Float indexers now. It should probably use Row.getRaw()?

As-is float/long ingestion will get an exception with unparseable values but otherwise it would work, `toTimeAndDims()` calls `row.getDimensions()` to get a `List<String>` of dimension names, but uses `Row.getRaw()` to read the row values:

```
        Object dimsKey = indexer.processRowValsToUnsortedEncodedKeyComponent(row.getRaw(dimension));
```

For point 2:
I think that's reasonable, it can just pull the value out of the list and treat it as a single value

For point 3 and general thoughts on ingesting nulls/unparseable values:
Maybe we should treat all null and unparseable ingested values as 0 for numeric columns. 

If we use "null" to indicate "invalid number", how would we represent this when persisting the index to disk? I don't think the existing segment format has a way to store nulls for numeric columns.

If we use NaN to indicate "invalid number" for Floats, it seems like we would have no equivalent for Longs. Are we okay with that inconsistency?
Also, I think we should fix the crashes in point 1 for 0.10.1, I'm working on a patch for that now
@leventov The places that still use the old logger do so because the logger is passed into a `LoggingEmitter` constructor, which only accepts a metamx logger.

@nishantmonu51 @drcrallen @jihoonson @gianm 

Does anyone else want to take a look at this patch again? If not, I'm planning on merging this tomorrow.
@akashdw thank you for the update. The latest patch looks good to me.
@gianm thanks for the update. Changes look good, but would you check the inspection failure?
They seem spurious, as they're in sections of the code that I haven't changed. I tried restarting the teamcity build.
@gianm yeah, it's fine now. The latest patch looks good to me.

Thanks for the review @jihoonson!

@fjy @leventov @b-slim, any further comments?
@gianm would you review again the latest patch?
I'm not planning to review

@chrisgavin 16 more malformed string format violations reported: https://teamcity.jetbrains.com/viewLog.html?buildId=1108816&tab=Inspection&buildTypeId=OpenSourceProjects_Druid_InspectionsPullRequests
@leventov thanks. I addressed your comments.

I'm not sure this really needs to be a 0.10.1 blocker, based on this comment.

> If a row with non-null unparseable values for a numeric dimension or a row with a numeric dimension missing is ingested, this would cause an NPE when sortFacts=false.

Because sortFacts is always true during ingestion. It's only false in groupBy v1 processing, which doesn't support numeric dimensions anyway. So the code path should never actually get hit in production.
@leventov do you have any thoughts on my comment about tests? This is one of the last patches blocking 0.10.1-rc2 so I'm hoping we can resolve it quickly.
Also the json serde needs to make sure it handles the values for positive and negative infinity as well
@gianm I have another patch I want to include into 0.10.1, not published yet
This was fixed in #4316 and will be available in 0.10.1. An RC is available now if you want to try it out: http://druid.io/download.html
K, Fine Thanks.
Thanks @leiwangx. Could you please fill out the CLA on http://druid.io/community/cla.html so we can accept your patch?
Thanks for adding some tests. I would prefer one for doubleMin/doubleMax too but will not consider that blocking to the PR. Please resolve conflicts too and this looks good to me.

@gianm doubleMin/doubleMax bug couldn't probably exploited now. It needs to have EvalExpr of null converted from float column, I didn't find a way to do that so that Calcite's type checker doesn't complain.
@gianm he's covered by MMX
@drcrallen ah, thanks.
@chrisgavin also please fill the CLA http://druid.io/community/cla.html
Awesome work guys! Would it be possible to also add [Parquet Date-column support](https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/4423) into 0.10.1?
Is this still open?
@fedecasanova72 yes. @pjain1 is working on this in #4178.

Thanks @Fokko and thanks also for your contributions to this release. 0.10.1 is code-frozen at this point (other than blocker bug fixes) so #4423 will be included in the next release, 0.11.0. Even though 0.10.1 hasn't been released yet, 0.11.0 is already well underway, with 19 new patches (including yours): https://github.com/druid-io/druid/milestone/23?closed=1
@gianm was still looking to review this PR...

> @gianm was still looking to review this PR...

Ah, sorry, didn't realize that. I'd say keep reviewing and if you uncover anything that needs to change let's get it in to 0.10.1.
Thanks for the explanation. Lets wait for 0.11.0 then. Thanks!
Anyone know what the failure with the TeamCity inspection is? I don't think I have login access to that..
It looked spurious to me (didn't see any new errors) so I tried bouncing the teamcity job.
@jon-wei you have to click "Log in as guest" that will just redirect inside without any extra steps. It's silly that it's not done automatically.
@leventov cool, thanks for the info!
Thanks for your reviews @fjy and @leventov. I'd like to get a few more eyes on this just to see what other people think. Let's keep it open for a bit and bring it up in a dev sync too.

Hm, the TeamCity build reports 13 new inspection errors, but those aren't in any of the files changed by this PR (did something go wrong with the inspection?)

Should we bounce the TeamCity build here (how do we do that?)
Hmm, it looks like triggering a custom build is not allowed for me. I'll close and reopen this pr.

> Also I have a general question about this PR - why do we need to add float-precision aggregators?

@leventov If you don't need double precision then it is a wast of storage to store numbers as 64bits instead of 32bits
@jihoonson I think "multiValueDelimiter" for each dimension is much too complex for user, perhaps it is not a common need.
@leventov Can you help to review my code, please?
@leventov thanks for reviewing this, any more comments ?

@leventov does this really need to be in 0.10.1?

@fjy if not `druid.extensions.moduleExcludeList` will appear in a released version, that is better to avoid. Plus we were not really able to run some Spark tasks without this PR, so not including it may be blocking for some users.

@leventov I used FastMath simply because it was faster than Math and I was ok with the precision trade-offs for this particular use-case. The objective was to keep the performance of the balancing comparable to what it was prior to #2972.

@jihoonson completely agree this is not a unit test, since it doesn't verify anything. It is just a qualitative test you would want to run if we decided to change the hash function used in the cache. The reason it was created in the first place was that the initial hash function used for cache keys was not very uniformly distributed, causing very uneven cache load across cache nodes.

We should probably just mark the test as `@Ignore` and add a comment to the cache code to remind us to verify even key distribution using this test in the event that someone decides to use a new hash function.
@xvrl thanks. I raised #4527.
@leventov wtf are these teamcity inspections and how do we disable them?
The TC error seems spurious, it refers to files that were not edited in this patch. I tried re-triggering the job.
@gianm thank you for the review!
Would you elaborate on how DI of querying-related stuffs blocks peons from running with Spark/Hadoop tasks?
The ci failure is due to https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/4530.

@jihoonson it's because we include our own extensions with configuration options for realtime peons, and they sneak into configuration for Spark peons. Those config options couldn't be instantiated on Spark peons, because we already exclude some other extensions/modules on them, I don't remember for what exact reason.
Duplicated by https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/4528

It's interesting because according to https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/MATH-1422 "FastMath" may not actually be faster, but OTOH is is supposed to be more precise.

FYI @dgolitsyn
@niketh any comments here?
Yes I got this error and I was using Java 1.7. Thanks. I installed 1.8 and it works fine now. I would suggest to close this.

@leventov I only used `FastMath.exp()`, and in this particular case I do remember it being faster. It is quite possible that as time goes by, with better hardware and improved JIT this may not hold forever. If you have data showing it does not help much, I wouldn't have any objection in removing the fastmath dependency.
@jihoonson could you please merge this PR?
I'll review tonight.
